page.title: 04LEISURE.Trosley Park.
page.content: Trosley Country Park was originally part of the Trosley Towers Estate which was owned by the Waterlow family. During the early 1970's the area was derelict and wild. In 1973 Kent County Council bought the area. Three years later the 160 acre park was opened to the public. The main pathway that runs through the centre of the park was once Hamilton Coach Drive which led up to the Estate. The land is dominated by deciduous trees. The trees that are most common are Oak,Hornbeam,Ash,Beech and Sweet Chestnut. Yew and European Larch are the only coniferous species.The park also has some open grazing land.On these slopes you can find some rare wild orchids.The park receives approximatly 10,000 visitors a year and between 250 and 300 cars a week during the summer.
